column2: The Schomburgk Line

Following the dissolution of Gran Colombia, its unsettled and remote eastern frontier in Essequibo has been left unorganized and unprotected. Following our acquisition of Guyana from the Dutch, we inherited a territorial dispute over Essequibo with Gran Colombia which disputed the former Spanish treaty. Thus we have legal justification to seize this patch of jungle without conflict. The Royal Geographical Society of London recommends we send Sir Robert Hermann Schomburgk to explore the region and delineate a proper border with Venezuela, as his work on surveying the Virgin Island of Anegada was quite impressive.

Abusing flimsy claims of inheritance of responsibilities from treaties between the Spanish and the Dutch, Britain has occupied Essequibo. With our recently nascent country barely posessing an army of note, there is nothing we can do to resist the Brits.

After resigning from the presidency, Bolívar made his way to Cartagena de Indias to board a ship and settle down abroad. However, he rested in the Customs House of Santa Marta as his health made travel difficult. As his condition worsened, he needed a transfer to a quieter place and moved to a farm located in San Pedro Alejandrino on the outskirts of the city, where he entered the full care of his trusted family doctor. Initially optimistic, both he and his doctor eventually recognized the severity of the condition, leading to Bolívar writing his will and instructing his entourage how to proceed in the event of his death. \nAfter the passage of morning marked by an increasing decline of vital signs, the silence of the house's main hall, occupied by the aides, military leadership of the Patriot Army and Bolívar's closest friends, was interrupted by the words of his doctor inviting them to the next room to witness the great liberator's last moments. Surrounded by his entourage, and after a long but calm agony, Simón Bolívar died at 1 PM, 3 minutes and 55 seconds on Friday, December 17, 1830.

'Colombians: You have witnessed my efforts to raise freedom where tyranny once reigned. I have worked with selflessness, abandoning my fortune and even my tranquility. I separated from command when I was persuaded that you distrusted my detachment. My enemies abused your credulity and they trampled on what is most sacred to me, my reputation and my love of freedom. I have been a victim of my persecutors, who have led me to the doors of the tomb. I forgive them. As I disappear from your midst, my affection tells me that I must make a manifestato of my last wishes. I do not aspire to any other glory than the consolidation of Colombia. All of you must work for the inestimable good of the Union: The people obeying the government to be free from anarchy, the ministers of the sanctuary directing their prayers to heaven, and the military using their sword to preserve the peace. Colombians! My last wishes are for the happiness of the country. If my death contributes to the end of the parties and the consolidation of the Union, I shall go to the grave in peace.'  -Simón Bolívar
The Apulo Convention

Gran Colombia is doomed. Without Bolívar, no leadership can emerge with enough legitimacy in the people's eyes to keep the country unified. With Ecuador, Venezuela and Panama in revolt, perhaps it is time to accept the inevitability of partition rather than spill more of our countrymen's blood. Accordingly, President Rafael Urdaneta has called for a convention to officially dissolve the union of Colombia and create a new state within the territories still under stable federal control.

Since 1828, Simón Bolívar has attempted to deal with Gran Colombia's national crises and keep the country united by assuming dictatorial powers. At present, however, has finally seen that this course of action has not kept the union together, but divided it ever more severely. He has now arrived at the conclusion that it would be best for Gran Colombia if he, El Libertador, resigned and left the presidency to an heir more capable of resolving national division. This course of action, however, risks creating ever more uncertainty. Gran Colombia was founded with Bolívar at the helm--his name is a byword for the country writ large, and his rule has been integral to Colombia's national identiy. What will happen to the nation after his resignation?

Led by the traitorous Colonel Juan Eligio Alzuru, Panama has declared its independence following the example of Venezuela and Ecuador. However, many inhabitants of Panama wish to remain as part of Colombia. Several officers have already voiced their opposition to Alzuru. It wouldn't be far-fetched to expect this independence movement to be short-lived unlike those in Venezuela and Ecuador.

Informed of the secession of Venezuela and Bolívar's death, the assembly of the district of the South has declared independence, founding the state of Ecuador. The departments of Quito, Azuay and Guayaquil are now under the supreme rule of Juan Jose Flores, the head of government.

Meeting in the council of Valencia, the assembly of the northern district chose the town for being the residence of hero of the wars against Spain, General José Antonio Páez who has been agitating against the government of Gran Colombia for years. Additionally, the town was the site of the separatist movement La Cosiata that occurred between 1826 and 1829. While the assembly's rhetoric was anti-Bolivarian from the start, once it had been informed of Bolívar's death, it took a turn for a worse. The assembly ultimately ceremoniously announced its independence from Gran Colombia as the state of Venezuela under the leadership of General Páez himself.

General Tomás Herrera has lead a counterrevolt against Juan Eligio Alzuru to put an end to Panamanian independence and repatriate to Colombia. While his revolt is seeing a lot of success, he needs the support of the people. The question lies in their loyalty to Colombia. Will they work towards continued self-sovereignty or reintegration to Colombia?

Executed by General Tomás Hererra, Alzuru's revolt is no more. Panama has returned to Colombian rule amid much jubilation. Many hope the same may occur in Venezuela or Ecuador, but those hopes are clearly in vain.
Colonize the Galapagos Islands

The Galapagos Islands are a hotspot of biodiversity, having been separate from the mainland for thousands of years. It also serves as an excellent naval base in the Pacific to project our influence. We must settle it before another country acts first!

The Colombian Constitution

Now that the situation has stabilized, the constitutional assembly has finished its deliberations and formulated a constitution. It establishes the separation of powers, the responsibilities of public officials, the duty to protect the Catholic church and the unitary form of government with decentralized local assemblies. Furthermore, it divides congress into an upper and lower house and sets its legislative terms.

Simón Bolívar's years as dictator of Gran Colombia have done the union no good. His unquestioned reign has even been compared by many to that of the kings of Spain. Recognizing what is best for the union, he has called for a new constitutional assembly to create a constitution for Gran Colombia in a last-ditch effort to prevent its dissolution.

After much trial and tribulation, Gran Colombia is united once more. El Libertador can rest easy knowing that the Bolivarian legacy shall continue. However, now that the crisis of secession is averted, we must ask ourselves what lies in our future. How will we govern ourselves to ensure that Gran Colombia will survive and not collapse once more?

Some days ago riots started in the town of Merthyr Tydfil, north of Cardiff, and today there are already reports of it expanding into all Wales, being an all-out rebellion. It's the first time a red flag is seen in a workers' revolt, being a symbol of the workers. They protest against the lowering of their wages and general unemployment, and among the shouts were cries of "Caws a bara" (cheese and bread), "Annibyniaeth" (independence) and "I lawr gyda'r Brenin" (down with the king), being a clear threat to the monarchy. Do we give them more rights or we protect the monarchy?

On a night in 1835, a fire broke out in a five-story warehouse at 25 Merchant Street, at the intersection of Hanover Street. As it spread, gale-force winds blowing from the northwest towards the East River spread the fire. It could be seen from Philadelphia, approximately 80 miles away. At the time of the fire, major water sources were frozen in temperatures as low as -17°F, forcing the firefighters to drill holes to access liquid water, which later refroze around the houses and pipes. Efforts were made to deprive the fire of fuel by demolishing surrounding buildings, but there was insufficient gunpowder. Later in the next evening, a detachment of U.S. Marines returned with gunpowder and stopped the fire. During the day and a half that it burned, the fire killed 2 civilians and in total destroyed 660 buildings, resulting in property damage estimated between 20-25 million. How much shall we invest for the reconstruction of New York?
Fully fund reconstruction efforts.
Send the minimum amount to help.
We can't afford anything right now.

News has reached us that a supposedly nonpolitical country fair celebrated at Hambach Castle, near Neustadt der Weinstraße in the Palatinate turned into a demonstration in support of German unity. Provoked by liberal intellectuals, they established democratic associations which collide with our reactionary policies. In the crowd shouts could be heard while thousands held up their hands: \n"Wir wollen sein ein einzig Volk von Bruedern, In keiner Noth uns trennen und Gefahr" (We swear to be a nation of true brothers, never to part in danger and in death) and "Wir wollen frei sein wie die Vaeter waren, Eher den Tod, als in der Knechtechaft leben." (We swear we will be free as were our sires, and sooner die than live in slavery). The news are already expanding to nearby towns, and similar "nonpolitical county fairs" are starting to be planned in other parts of the Palatinate, expanding Pan-German ideas to the population, being a threat to our independence and our policies in the topic. Do we silence the news or let the Pan-German ideas expand to bordering regions?
German unification wouldn't be that bad...
Silence the news.

A week ago, a supposedly nonpolitical country fair celebrated at Hambach Castle, near Neustadt der Weinstraße in the Bavarian Palatinate turned into a demonstration in support of German unity. Provoked by liberal intellectuals, they established democratic associations which collided with Bavaria's reactionary policies. In the crowd shouts could be heard while thousands held up their hands: \n"Wir wollen sein ein einzig Volk von Bruedern, In keiner Noth uns trennen und Gefahr" (We swear to be a nation of true brothers, never to part in danger and in death) and "Wir wollen frei sein wie die Vaeter waren, Eher den Tod, als in der Knechtechaft leben." (We swear we will be free as were our sires, and sooner die than live in slavery). The news are already expanding to nearby towns, and similar "nonpolitical county fairs" are starting to be planned in other parts of the Palatinate. Bavaria has let us know the news, and our population could join the movement if it isn't stopped now. Should we stop the news from further spreading among our population, or should we let them all know the truth?
German unification wouldn't be that bad...
Silence the news.
The Polish Uprising of $YEAR$

Ever since their brief independence during the Napoleonic Wars and our subsequent annexation of the formerly Prusso-Austrian region, our subjects in Congress Poland have become increasingly restless. An spontaneous uprising has erupted, caused by the revolt of young Polish officers led by lieutenant Piotr Wysocki. With the rebellion spreading like wildfire among the Poles, the peoples of Lithuania, Belarus, and the right-bank Ukraine have also been whipped up, threatening further revolutions. We must ready our armies for battle, for letting Poland go would not only be a show of weakness towards the other great powers but would also serve to inspire widespread insurrection among our subjects.
Prepare for war.
Let them be free.
Onwards to Poland! §BPlay as Poland§W

A spontaneous protest by young Polish officers from the military academy of the Army of Congress Poland has quickly erupted into a widespread insurrection across $COUNTRY$, supported by high-ranking Polish and Lithuanian officers and politicians. The eyes of all of Europe are upon $COUNTRY$, and if they deal with the insurgents too harshly it may hurt their relations with other European powers. If they do not, however, the uprising will surely spread even further.

A spontaneous protest by young Polish officers from the military academy of the Army of Congress Poland has quickly erupted into a widespread insurrection across $COUNTRY$, supported by high-ranking Polish and Lithuanian officers and politicians.
A spontaneous protest by young Polish officers from the military academy of the Army of Congress Poland has quickly erupted into a widespread insurrection across $COUNTRY$.
The Polish Uprising of $YEAR$

4 months ago, a spontaneous protest by young Polish officers from the military academy of the Army of Congress Poland had quickly erupted into a widespread insurrection across Poland, supported by high-ranking Polish and Lithuanian officers and politicians. Now our Tzar demands the complete and unconditional surrender of Poland and announces that the Poles should surrender to the grace of their Emperor. This can only be made by war.
To arms!.
Let them be free.
Onwards to Poland!
The Rebellion is Crushed

Today, the remainder of the Polish army of over 20,000 men crossed the Russian frontier and laid down their arms at Brodnica in surrender to Russia--the last resistance in Poland. The war, during which 120 battles and skirmishes were fought and forty thousand Polish killed, came to a speedy end in $YEAR$. The Tsar has immediately passed edicts to make the land an integral part of Russia's territory, and the remaining Polish rebels are at his mercy.
There will be harsh reprisals.
Be lenient with them.
The January Uprising
The January Uprising
Subsidiary Alliance with Bahawalpur

Bahawalpur has been continually threatened by the Sikh Empire on its western border. To the Nawab, British suzerainty seems a better alternative than conquest by the Sikhs. Therefore, we should sign a treaty of protection with Bahawalpur to extend our rule in India.

The Malês, groups of Muslim African slaves from West Africa, planned a revolt against the townspeople and their masters. For years these men have been treated as chattel, used for nothing but tiring work. Their freedom? Nothing but a fragment of a distant past. But today is the day they fight to regain it. Today, their arms will break the shackles chaining them to the Pelourinho for another round of whips. Or so they claim.
The Malês have emerged victious in this war. We have nothing to choice but to accept their terms.
We have reconquered our lost lands in Bahia, taken from us by the Malê devils. It's time we restore rightful ownership over the Zona da Mata Baiana

3 days ago Nat Turner, an enslaved African-American preacher, had organized a rebellion of enslaved and free Black people in Southampton County, Virginia. Turner was recorded as "Nat" by Benjamin Turner, the man who enslaved him and his family. When Benjamin Turner died in 1810, under then-current laws which made slavery legal, Nat was inherited as property by Benjamin's son Samuel Turner. On February 12, 1831, he witnessed a solar eclipse that was visible from much of the southeastern United States, and was convinced that it was the sign for which he was waiting. He began preparations for an uprising against the enslavers in Southampton County by purchasing muskets. The last 3 days they have been waging terror in Southampton, but have been stopped today by local militias and detachments of men from the USS Natchez and USS Warren. Approximately 120 black people and around 60 white people died today.

Turner eluded capture for six weeks, but remained in Southampton County. On October 30, a White farmer named Benjamin Phipps discovered him hidden among the local Nottoway people, in a depression in the earth, created by a large, fallen tree that was covered with fence rails. While awaiting trial, Turner confessed his knowledge of the rebellion to attorney Thomas Ruffin Gray, who compiled what he claimed was Turner's confession. Today he got sentenced to death and hanged for "conspiring to rebel and making insurrection".

The turmoil in the São Pedro do Rio Grande do Sul province has exploded into a full blown revolt! The "Farrapos" have reached and conquered Porto Alegre and several towns in the province of São Pedro do Rio Grande do Sul. We must act now, otherwise who knows what these rebels can get up to if they ever manage to beat the Imperial Army.

Several Generals in our country have toyed with the idea of declaring a separate Republic known as the "Republica Rio-Grandense", Bento Gonçalves is still pondering weather or not to declare the Republic, but the time has come to make a final choice.

Liberal politicians in the province of São Pedro do Rio Grande do Sul have demanded more and more federalization of the Empire, repeating that currently they have small to no representation within the Monarchy.

News has reached us that slaves in Jamaica have risen up in a revolt to demand more freedom and a working wage of "half the going wage rate," which we can't provide. The enslaved laborers believed that the protest and resulting labor shortage alone could cause Britain to agree to their demands. Resorting to violence was only envisaged if our troops were to use it against them. Thus, when the army fired shots to dissolve an angry mob, they unwittingly caused a revolt of 60,000 slaves to begin, under the leadership of Samuel Sharpe, a former slave turned Baptist preacher.

News has reached us that slaves in Jamaica have risen up in a revolt to demand more freedom and a working wage of "half the going wage rate," which the British won't provide. The enslaved laborers believe that the protest and resulting labor shortage alone could cause Britain to agree to their demands. Resorting to violence was only envisaged if the British themselves were to use it against them. Thus, when British troops fired shots to dissolve an angry mob, they unwittingly caused a revolt of 60,000 slaves to begin, under the leadership of Samuel Sharpe, a former slave turned Baptist preacher.
We have conquered even more lands from those heretic Brazilians!
Jihad against Brazil
These heretic Brazilians should pay for what they made our people go through! We should expand all the way up to São Francisco!

The Cabanos have captured Belém! The rebelious forces in the north of Brazil have captured the provincial capital of Belém and have declared the Republic of Pará and are now at war with the Imperial government seeking independence.

The Great Trek has begun! From 1652 to 1806, the Cape Colony was a part of the Netherlands under the name "Kaapkolonie". Under this period, tons of Dutch people migrated down there for trading reasons. The Cape Colony was an important re-supply station for all trade coming from europe and further on to Asia. The Afrikaners (Dutch-Africans) still has the vast majority of the European population in the Cape Colony and during the last years the Afrikaners feel that they've been treated unfairly, especially when we declared in 1828 that the native Africans were to have human rights, when we declared English as the official language of the region when most Afrikaners spoke no English and just now, when we abolished slavery (Historically in 1834). In some places, 94% of the Afrikaners owned slaves, so this was a huge hit to their livelihood. 12000 Afrikaners are now on their way to become refugees in the vast wilderness of southern Africa! What should we do?
Build the Brest-Litovsk Fortress

It is time for our government to commission a fortress in the key strategic city of Brest-Litovsk, covering an intersection of the Bug and Mukhavets rivers. It is to be constructed in a star shape, with barracks lining its banks on three sides and a citadel on an island in the center. The fort will accommodate 12,000 soldiers in total.

Antonio José de Sucre y Alcalá or the 'Gran Mariscal de Ayacucho' has been found dead on a a trail leading South. Sucre, a brilliant general and tactician who led the pro-independence forces to victory against the Spanish royalists in the decisive battles of Pichincha and Ayacucho, was perhaps Simón Bolívar's greatest ally. After vanquishing the Spaniards, he served as president of Bolivia until a strong anti-Bolívarian movement led to his resignation. In face of the imminent collapse of Gran Colombia, he headed South to discourage the secession of Ecuador. Seeing the danger that a beloved hero of the war of independence poses to their plot, the pro-Ecuadorian elements under Juan José Flores hired an assassin to murder Sucre, preventing his interference.
Österreichischer Lloyd

Several sea transport insurance companies, banking houses and numerous individual shareholders, among them the Austrian politician Karl Ludwig von Bruck, have come together to form a shipping company. Based in Trieste, it would begin constructing new steamers to transports passengers and goods and bring news from overseas. With this much backing, the company would be sure to become the prime shipping company in the Austrian Empire.

The Palace of Westminster has burned down today in a sudden conflagration. According to the investigation on the ground, a bundle of tally sticks used for accounting by the Exchequer was disposed of in two underfloor stoves under the House Floors, which caused a chimney fire. The fire then seeped through the building and caused the walls to catch fire as well. Before it was put out, flames engulfed all of Westminster Palace and left intact only five of its buildings. Reconstruction will have to begin immediately.

After the loss of Central America by the Mexican Empire, secessionist movements both by Hispanic and indigenous nationalists have plagued our fledgling state of $COUNTRY$. Anastasio Aquino, a leader of the Nahualco indigenous people, has staged a rebellion in the department of La Paz after his brother was arrested by the owner of the hacienda the two worked on. He soon amassed an army of over 2,000 men and attacked towns across La Paz. His army will require the mobilization of our troops the way all-out war would.
Establish a School of Medicine for Women

A French doctor named Antoine Clot has held an esteemed medical practice in Egypt for 5 years as Surgeon-in-Chief of the Armies. Before he arrived from France, our country did not yet have a medical care system: since then he has worked as director of the first medical school in Egypt, Kasr al-Aini Medical School, and even has been made chief surgeon for Muhammad Ali Pasha. Clot is a force of Egypt's modernization. With this modernization comes a need to bring women into the fold. We should grant Clot's request to open a women's medical school.

The always separatist-minded Serbs have launched a rebellion against us in Bosnia, led by a radical Orthodox priest named Jovica Ilic. It was sparked when Ilic petitioned former Prince Miloš Obrenovic for support for an armed revolt, then met with fellow priests who each agreed to help organize participants. Violence is currently concentrated in Tuzla and around Banja Luka. The most worrying violence, however, has come in the nahiye of Derventa in Posavina, where Odzak has been set on fire. The revolt has been crushed in three days, but insurrections continue throughout Bosnia.

In the rural town of Uster, Zürich canton, locals gathered today in a peaceful assembly to protest the overrepresentation of the cantonal capital compared to Zürich's rural parts. They argue that Uster's livelihood has been neglected, causing its locals to languish in poverty and remain largely uneducated. They also call for a new constitution to overhaul the governance of all Switzerland's cantons. For citizens to call for the constitution's repeal or amendment is unheard of: they are legally prohibited from petitioning the government to make such changes. Nevertheless, the liberal ideas left behind by Napoleon's rule clearly are still showing their influence. This will definitely not be the last call by our people for fair representation.

Never before have our people made such strong demands against our government while also not shedding a drop of blood. Today, discontent locals in the Freiamt region of Aargau canton led an uprising in protest of reduced rural representation in the constitution. They demonstrated their resolve by organizing themselves into militias. Despite clashes across Freiamt where about 6,000 total militia members confronted Swiss forces--with both sides prepared to engage--not a single shot was fired. Miraculously, the government agreed to a revision to the constitution and negotiated an end to the uprising. This marks an indelible end to the illiberal, undemocratic government before Napoleon's time, where the government could get away with unequal or unfair representation of the people. Aargau was ruled particularly heavy-handedly by governor Johannes Herzog, who has been claimed to want to run a duchy instead of a canton. Well, his tyranny ends now.

The tyrannical general Resid Mehmed has at long last acted on the Ottomans' behalf to tighten their choke hold on the Albanian people. The general invited 500 Albanian beys to attend a meeting where they would be rewarded for their loyalty to their government. When they arrived, the beys were greeted by a military procession--but the next thing they knew, upon a hand signal from Mehmed, the Turkish soldiers opened fire on the beys and killed them all. \n\nThe Ottomans have removed the one element in the government we could count on to stop our full annexation. Lest we let our dream of an independent Albania die out, we must rally our people and declare a war for our liberation against the Ottomans--right now. Our surviving political leaders have already organized soldiers to do so.

General Resid Mehmed has taken rash action to tighten our grip on the administration in Albania by committing a massacre against Albanian beys, traditional chieftains. About 500 of them were invited to a meeting where they were told they were to be rewarded for their loyalty to the government at. They attended, and after their arrival they were greeted by a ceremonial solute parade of soldiers, which was in fact an ambush. Upon a sign from Resid Mehmed, they fired upon the beys, slaughtering them all. This massacre comes as a response to the behavior of the Pashaliks of Yanina and Shkodra, who had ambitions to finally create an independent Albania. But the Albanian people will not stand for this--they have already taken up arms to challenge our forces head-on.

After Sultan Mahmud II brutally betrayed us with the now-infamous Massacre of the Albanian Beys, he invaded our homeland and tried to rob us of our autonomy. However, the war did not develop as he had hoped: Against all odds, the Ottoman armies were repulsed by our pasha, Mustafa Bushati. As a result, instead of losing our autonomy, we have won independence by clutching victory from the jaws of defeat. As a new era dawns upon our country, Mustafa Bushati has assumed a new title: A pasha no longer, he is now the Sultan of Albania. Now that we are forever free from the Ottoman yoke, a bright future awaits.
The Bavarian Ludwig Railway

Railways are the future of transportation. With their recent invention in Britain promising speedy commutes between cities, it is not hard to imagine that Germany would benefit greatly from building their own. The Royal Privileged Ludwig Railway Company may obtain a charter for building a railway in Bavaria right now--also the first in all of Germany.

A series of articles anonymously published in New York newspaper The Sun are causing a stir. They claim there exists not only life but an entire civilization on Earth's moon, with no one having previously observed them. It features fantastical illustrations of the moon's geography and creatures such as a man with bat wings, which the articles claim are common inhabitants on the moon. These claims are clearly false, but they nevertheless have proven beneficial for The Sun's circulation, allowing the paper to claim a new height of success. The articles' author, meanwhile, has yet to be revealed.

Lyon, a city dominated by silk-based manufacturing, has descended into chaos in the wake of riots by silk workers, who are known in French as canuts. The workers, reacting to a drop in wages, are demanding a minimum price to be imposed on silk products and seized weapons from the national guard to enforce this demand. They soon engaged the national guard and the military in battle, leaving Lyon entirely in their hands. However, the government was able to retake the city without further bloodshed and without conceding to the workers' demands.
The Conquest of Algiers

Tension between France and the Deylik of Algiers, an autonomous part of the Ottoman Empire, has escalated due to Algerian pirates raiding European ships. With these Barbary Pirates being a major thorn in our backside, it's about time we show them their place and conquer Algiers for ourselves. We even have the perfect casus belli: a provocation by Hussein Bey, who struck the French consul, Pierre Deval, with a fan during a heated argument over both countries' trade debts to each other.

A devastating earthquake has hit Concepción and nearby Talcahuano today at 11:30 AM. The quake combined with a resulting tsunami have left Concepción destroyed, with most buildings in ruins. Miraculously, though, casualties have remained low, with only 50 people reported dead. The lack of deaths is attributable to how the quake was slow to intensify and happened at about high noon, allowing locals to get to safety in time. Charles Darwin happened to be in Concepción as the earthquake struck, on a stop for the second voyage of the HMS Beagle. He would describe the quake as such: "I happened to be on shore, and was lying down in the wood to rest myself. It came on suddenly, and lasted two minutes, but the time appeared much longer. The rocking of the ground was very sensible . . . The people rushed out of doors in the greatest alarm. It is these accompaniments that create that perfect horror of earthquakes, experienced by all who have thus seen, as well as felt, their effects."

An assassination attempt was made on King Louis-Philippe today at the hands of Republican terrorists. During a royal procession held near the Place de la République in Paris, conspirators Giuseppe Marco Fieschi, Theodore Pépin, and Philippe Morey discharged a homemade volley gun with 25 barrels at the King and his soldiers. The barrage killed 18 people but only minorly wounded Louis-Philippe, and Fieschi was immediately captured. \n\nIt has since then been discovered that four barrels of the volley gun did not fire due to the components' failure. Surely more would have died, including the King, had the weapon worked as intended. Fieschi is imprisoned and awaiting trial, while Pépin and Morey are still at large.
Expand our Principality

We were established in 1399 and subjugated by the Turks in 1554. We have stayed their peaceable vassal for several centuries, but Mir Mohammed has other plans - the expansion of our army and land. A good first step should be taking on the emirate to our north, Bahdinan.

Soran was established in 1399 and subjugated by the Turks in 1554. Lately, they have begun waging war on neighboring principalities, hoping to become the dominant Kurdish tribe. They have reached our borderlands and issued an ultimatum - surrender or face the consequences.

Our vassal, the Soran Emirate, had suspiciously been building up its army without an apparent reason. A week ago, their armies entered our vassal to their north, Bahdinan, and since then they have been at war. Soran still is a loyal vassal on paper, but it could easily devolve into a war for independence very soon. As concerning as the situation is, must we delay intervention, we will be better prepared to put down Soran, and Bahdinan had never been too loyal anyway, as the local Yazidis have influence in their government.

Our vassal, the Soran Emirate, had suspiciously been building up its army without an apparent reason. Today, their armies have entered our vassal to their north, Bahdinan, and advanced. Soran still is a loyal vassal on paper, but it could easily devolve into a war for independence very soon. Bahdinan has asked for our intervention to conserve the stability of the Qajar-Ottoman border and the balance of power of the Kurdish principalities.
Conquer Kirkük

The Baban Emirate has always sought to weaken our state and once occupied half of our lands. Their emir is greedy and is allied with the Yazidis, to whom he grants amnesties and asylum. The people of Kirkük are constantly oppressed by Baban, and factions of the local militias have signaled that they'd join our offensive. It might be time to fix the greatest error the Soran Emirate has ever done - letting Baban exist.

Baban was once a great emirate that ruled lands in what is now Soran and Ardalan, but the greed of the Ottoman and Qajar Empires and the contemporary rise in Soran's power have made us weaker and weaker. Today, Sorani troops have crossed the border in the north and into Kerkûk and militias in the region are siding with the invader. Our situation is precarious, but the Ottomans are distracted elsewhere, and their delayed response could bring suffering to the rest of the Ottoman Kurdish population.

Baban was once a great emirate that ruled lands in what is now Soran and Ardalan, but their constant rebellions made them lose land to their neighbors through our and the Qajar's favors. Today, Sorani troops have crossed into Kerkûk, Baban, and are preparing to lay siege to the city. The Baban Emir has insisted that we don't intervene, and our army is not in conditions to attack Soran. Must we delay intervention, we will be better prepared to put down Soran, and we had already studied a campaign to pacify Baban's infidel Yarsinian and Yazidi populations, which influence their government, so this invasion in reality is a favor to our administration.

Baban was once a great emirate that ruled lands in what is now Soran and Ardalan, but their constant rebellions made them lose land to their neighbors through our and the Qajar's favors. Today, Sorani troops have crossed into Kerkûk, Baban, and are preparing to lay siege to the city. The Baban Emir has insisted that we intervene to end the Sorani army's expansion throughout Kurdistan, but our army is not in the best of shapes...
Ally Bohtan and take Tasini

The Bohtan are a powerful emirate that rules the city of Cizre and its surroundings, including Zaco. Their ruler, Bedir Khan Beg, also wants to liberate Kurdistan from Ottoman hands and has a similar approach. The lands of Singal are full of Yazidis that raid both their and our lands, and together we will be able to stop them.

The Soran Emirate has sent a request for an alliance between our two nations against the Yazidi nation of Tasini. In exchange for our support and ceding Zaco, we will become their allies and fight together against the Ottomans. Should we accept we are expected to send troops to help with the invasion of Tasini. We, though, have to be careful with Soran's ruler, as his greed will grow the more land he takes.

Bohtan has agreed to our alliance to liberate our borders from the Yazidi of Tasini. They are expected to send their troops to Sinjar, but they might take some days to mobilize their army. Regardless, with this alliance we will be able to successfully fend off any Ottoman incursion!

Soran has sent their army to our border and declared war to 'pacify our Yazidi population.' Their genocidal intentions are clear from miles away, but our chances to survive are few - the Ottomans support such an invasion and have looked the other way to most of their invasions.

The Soran Emirate has launched an invasion once more, this time towards Tasini and its Yazidi population. They are prone to rebellion, so any pacification of the region would actually be beneficial to our cause. Bohtan seems to agree with this stance, and some of their militias are present in the Sorani armies, so we might want to hold our horses for some more months.

The Soran Emirate has launched an invasion once more, this time towards Tasini and its Yazidi population. They are prone to rebellion, so any pacification of the region would actually be beneficial to our cause. This stance, though, might be making our rule in Kurdistan weaker and weaker, so an intervention would put an end to this trend - if we were to win.

The Soran Emirate has asked that our armies join them in their invasion of Tasini, but moving our armies from Cizre might make us more vulnerable to an invasion by them. Soran has signaled to its local allies that we are not to be trusted, so we should be cautious.

The Bohtan Emirate has refused to sign any alliances that contain ceding Zaco, ending any and all negotiations. They cite that their territorial integrity is key to a working relationship with our nation and that under no circumstances would they sign 'such a one-sided treaty.' The Ottomans are clearly behind this act, as their emir would never write like this to our great emir.

Bohtan has not sent significant forces to their border with Tasini for days now, and today they have sent an envoy saying that the Emir has left our alliance. Bohtan's emir might think we are traitors, but this is clearly a sign of the opposite.
Occupy Bohtan

The Bohtan Emirate is no more than a roadblock in our successful campaigns, and their Emir is constantly collaborating with the enemy. To realize our ultimate goal - we must end Bohtan's autonomy once and for all.

Soran has started a campaign to turn us into their satellite, as they deem us 'untrustworthy.' Our state is in grave peril, and the Soran Emirate is very powerful. We must ask the Ottoman Empire for help, or our population will suffer this occupation greatly.

The Bohtan Emirate has defied our rule more than once, and their recent actions in their alliance with Soran have confirmed our view of Cizre. Today, Sorani troops have crossed into the Bohtan Emirate in the Sorani's goal to centralize our Kurdish possessions. If we were to let them continue, they might end up annexing the entirety of our Kurdish emirates and principalities, and the more they conquer, the stronger they become. It might be time to intervene to end this trend.

Our great and powerful army has lost against the Emirate of Soran, a puny and defenseless statelet and a rump shell of a nation. This should not repeat itself, or we'll find ourselves encircled on all sides by the European powers.

In a great show of military prowess, our Kurdish state, deemed by many powers as weak and illegitimate, has won a war against the Great Ottoman Empire. This victory will be celebrated for centuries to come, starting today.
Our army has lost in the field of battle, no hope is left for our people and for the destiny of Kurdistan. We hope that our lands will someday be liberated from the hands of the Ottomans.

Our great and invincible army has defeated the armies of the Emirate of Soran, and it is now up to us what will happen with what is left from it. What is for sure is that the Soran Emirate must be permanently pacified so they never pose a threat to us anymore.
Sign Ceasefire With Soran
The war in Soran is not going our way. With the numerous wars happening around the region, we would benefit from a short, 20-month ceasefire to reorganize and prepare for war.
The Ottoman Empire has proposed that we ceasefire for 20 months. It would benefit both parties, and we'd be able to hold onto conquered territories, Mosul and Dijarbakir.

The Soran Emirate has agreed to the 20-month ceasefire, and we can now prepare to restart our offensive. The Sorani Emirate will soon face our full force, and their dream of a unified Kurdistan will be no more.

The Soran Emirate has refused to cease fire against all expectations. They seem to believe they can get a more promising peace treaty when they are losing the war on all fronts. It is time to end Soran once and for all - Rewandiz must burn.
The war against the Baghdad Mamluks has been a success, and now we have to cede Baghdad to our overlords...

The fall of numerous cities in Southwestern Kurdistan has led to chaos and conflict throughout the region. An army led by Muhammad Kor has attacked multiple Assyrian and Yazidi settlements throughout Baban and Bahdinan, killing thousands and forcing others to migrate east and north. First he attacked settlements in Chemchemal and Kerkûk, killing more than seven thousand people and forcing more to escape to Suleymaniyah. Afterward they marched on the lands of the Bahdinan, attacking Sheikhan, Akre and Tall Kayf and killing thousands. Those who survived, about 10 thousand Yazidis, mostly women and children, and their ruler, Ali Beg, were forced to death march from their ancestral lands into Ravanduz, where they were asked to convert to Islam. Most if not all of them rejected the request and were massacred in a waterfall 90 miles north of Hewlêr, now named the Ali Beg Waterfall in his honor.

Those who managed to survive tried swimming through the Tigris to reach Sinjar, but not many survived. Christians and other minorities have not been spared either, with most of the atrocities centered against them having occurred in Dêrik.

Sinjal is full of refugees, and our finances are strained, but we should prepare to defend our lands now more than ever from a potential attack from Soran.

The Sorani expedition into Tasini has caused an unimaginable human toll on the local population. The Tasini mountains are home to most of the Yazidi that have survived the massacres in Dêrik, Zaco, Akre, Tall Kayf and Kerkûk, and Muhammad Beg's army was dead set on massacring everyone that escaped their 'pacification' of Bahdinan and Baban. Today, Muhammad Beg's army has dealt a huge blow to the local Yazidi population, killing up to 15 thousand people and forcing many to escape to Assyrian lands in Tur Abdin, Western Bohtan, where they are protected by them. Thousands are now homeless as Sinjar and 200 other settlements have been burned and their wealth taken.

A battle between the Yazidi-Assyrian resistance in Tur Abdin, Siirt, and forces led by Muhammad Beg has occurred today. The Assyrian-Yazidi joint army, against all odds, has been able to force Beg to retreat and sign a treaty that prohibits him from further attacks on Tur Abdin or the surrounding regions, bringing an end to the genocide he was perpetrating in the region.
Attack Hakkari

Hakkari is a powerful Kurdish emirate with a large Assyrian minority that is centered on the Hakkari mountains. The mountains of Hakkari were once part of our emirate, but the Ottoman Empire forced us to give up lands in the region after our defeat three hundred years ago. Now it is time to undo this injustice and conquer Hakkari.

The Emirate of Soran has attacked our border posts today after intense drills were made close to our borders and the state of Bahdinan fell into their hands. The Sorani are powerful, but we have an ace uo our sleeves - the Assyrian population is highly trained in battle and know the Hakkari Mountains by heart. We could ask the Ottomans for help, which they could reject, or take a chancne at defending ourselves from the Sorani menace with the Assyrians.

The Emirate of Soran has attacked Hakkari today to take it from our hands. Should we be able to send troops, we might be able to successfully defend them, but the Sorani army is still strong and completely able to win a war against us.
Reshid Mehmed Pasha's Campaign in Northern Kurdistan

With the defeats in Lower Kurdistan, Reshid Mehmed Pasha has suggested that we launch an expedition to vassalize the Kurdish states of the north of Kurdistan, from the small semi-autonomous emirates of Erzurum to the more powerful states to their south, with control over extensive territories. This expedition should help pacify most of Kurdistan and bring an end to the local revolts, sending governors to the highlands and establishing control over those that do not agree with the policies.

The Ottoman Empire has demanded that we give in to the governor of Sivas, Reshid Mehmed Pasha's demands - that we become vassals of the Ottoman Empire and cease to send help to the rebelling emirates south of us. This, of course, would mean an end to our de facto independent rule while maintaining most of our sovereignty.
Conquer The Rest of The Kurdish Principalities

With our victory against Hakkari we can now look further north. The principalities of Bitlis, Bayazid and Zirqan have long been largely neutral to our actions in Southern Kurdistan, but our victory in Hakkari has scared most from allying with us, some having even asked for help from the Ottoman Empire. It is clear that to keep our sovereignty intact, we must invade these principalities and secure our border with the Ottoman Empire.

The Soran Emirate has demanded that we join their fight against the Ottoman Empire, or we'll be invaded. This is a clear violation of the neutrality we had enjoyed up to this point, and the only guarantor of our independence is the Ottoman Empire. It may be time to ask for help from the Ottoman Empire and declare war on the Soran Emirate to end its independence and oppression of fellow Kurds.

The Soran Emirate has attacked $FROMCOUNTRY$ in a new offensive in Northern Kurdistan. They have not asked for help, as they see the battle lost and prefer that we declare war on Soran when we are better prepared, but the decision to intervene is up to us.

The Soran Emirate has attacked $FROMCOUNTRY$ in a new offensive in Northern Kurdistan. The Principality in question has asked for help, as the Sorani army is powerful and prepared for this kind of assault, but we might not be able to intervene due to treaties with Soran. Regardless, the choice to break a truce is ours.
Occupy Mosul

The Vilayet of Mosul was promised to us in our treaty with the Ottoman Empire, but a rebelling province had control over the region at the time. We should send them an ultimatum to cede Mosul, or we'll have no choice but to declare war.

When the Ottoman Empire signed a peace treaty with the Ottoman Empire, their border was set in Samarra, south of Mosul. As we rebelled against the Ottoman Empire and took those lands, they never received all the lands they were promised. Today the Soran Emirate has sent us an ultimatum - cede Mosul, or the entirety of the Sorani military will be sent to burn $CAPITAL$ to the ground. The Sorani think they can force this treaty on us, but they have not seen our military prowess fending off the Ottoman Empire from our lands. Should they attack, the Sorani Emirate will be soundly defeated and our armies victorious once again. Long live $COUNTRY$!

$FROMCOUNTRY$ has refused to cede Mosul and does not abide by the treaty we signed with their de jure overlords. We have no other choice but to declare war, or we will be seen as weak and be attacked again by the Ottoman Empire.
Claim Qajar Kurdistan

Our armies have been strengthened by conquests once more, and it is only natural that we continue our expansion into the rest of Kurdistan under the Qajar Dynasty's control. They have oppressed the Kurds of the region for decades, and the Ardalan deserve to be annexed for helping Baban three hundred years ago annex us. It is time to unleash our military on the mountains of Ardalan and Urmia and place them under our great state.

The Sorani Emirate has just done its worst move since its invasion of Baban three hundred years ago - they have declared war on us to conquer the whole of Kurdistan. They think they can win against our great army, when they don't have support even inside our Kurdish community. The Sorani Emirate is destined to fall, and we will be the ones to place the last nail in their coffin.

Our great army has managed to overpower the Qajar Dynasty, and we now own the whole of their claim in Kurdistan. This victory is not the first or the last victory we will have against them, but we now must center our efforts further west and south.

We have been defeated in our war against the Soran Emirate after numerous blunders in the battlefield and the betrayal of our Kurdish community. We have no choice but to accept defeat and wait for the day we can regain these lost lands.
The Subjugation of Soran

While the Emirate of Soran has been driven back, the Emir still poses a threat to the region's stability. Letting his rule continue despite his rebellious actions may inspire other Kurdish chiefs to do the same.
Funding French Settlers in Algeria

Although our New World colonies are gone, our settler-colonial ventures are not yet over, still going strong in Algeria. But more often than not, these settlers will need a considerable amount of funding to ensure their livelihood in the new land. Thus, as the mother nation, it is seen as our duty to provide for their needs. The question is how much money we shall offer them, if at all.

With our newfound victory over the Algerians, we must continue the fight against the tribesmen who are holding out, rallying in the hinterland against colonial rule. Hussein Bey, the former ruler of Algeria has gone into exile in Naples as the populace has lost all confidence in his rule due to his defeat. In the East, Ahmed Bey ben Mohamed Sherif, the Bey of Constantine, has now claimed to be Hussein Bey's legitimate successor as ruler of Algeria. In this power vacuum, a new figure has emerged: Abdelkader ibn Muhieddine, a minor sharif and islamic scholar has rallied the tribes to resist us in unison. We know, however that such backwards, unorganized rabble cannot stop us! Soon, all of Algeria shall be ours! Vive la France!

Due to our calamitous defeat at the hands of the French and the loss of our capital, Algiers, the government has collapsed. Hussein Bey, the regent of Algiers, has gone into exile in Naples, having lost all vestiges of popular support. In the East, Ahmed Bey ben Mohamed Sherif, the Bey of Constantine, has now claimed to be Hussein Bey's legitimate successor as ruler of Algeria, pledging to drive out the French. In the rest of the former Bey's domains, a new leader has emerged: Abd al-Qadir ibn Muhyi al-Din, also known as Emir Abdelkader, an Islamic scholar and Sufi, has become both the religious and military leader of most of Algeria. Taking advantage of the power vacuum left by the fleeing Bey, Abdelkader has been elected as Amir al-Mu'minin or Emir by the disparate tribes of Algeria to unite them against their common foe: The French. Who will prevail remains to be seen.

France has pathetically attempted to conquer our great nation, and they have failed, as they had failed in Egypt in 1800, Haiti in 1804, and Russia in 1812. It is time to choose to either move forward as an independent nation or reapproach the Ottoman Empire for protection.
It is time to decide our policy of on the new settlers in Algeria and what they shall receive from the French state.

A rebellion has risen within the Sanjak of Lazistan, resisting the installment of derebeys--local governors--who are cruel and care most about consolidating Ottoman control. This comes as a result of a blood feud between the Hazinedaroglu and Tuzcuoglu families, both of whom have vied for control of Lazistan as derebeys. Derebey Adjara Osman Hazinedaroglu has used his authority to levy large taxes on his subjects, which contributed to food scarcity in 1829 and 1830. Locals have now begun to stop paying taxes and rebel, with rival Derebey Tahir Aga Tuzcuoglu as their leader. We cannot allow Tuzcuoglu to continue his defiance. We must put an end to the rabble.

Inspired by our victory, the Pontic Greeks have decided to rise up against the Ottoman Empire. The time has come to join them as brothers in arms against the Ottoman oppressors, as we can only defeat them together.
Inspired by the Lazi victory, the Pontic Greeks have decided to rise up against us. We must end this revolt and put an end to rebellions in the Pontic lands.

Lazistan has been pacified and plundered by our army. With the Tuzcuoglu family removed from power, we can tighten our grip on the province and ensure its governors will be unconditionally loyal to us.

The Uruguayan Constitution of $YEAR$

Inspired by the liberal ideas of the American and French revolutionaries, calls for a constitution firmly establishing Uruguay as a representative democracy are echoing within the government. Under this constitution, Uruguay will be represented by a president and a two-chamber legislative branch consisting of the Chamber of Representatives and the Chamber of Senators. Meanwhile, supreme legal power will be put in the hands of the Supreme Court of Justice. The constitution will also strengthen the federal government's authority--so much so that our country will be considered a unitary republic. Nevertheless, the constitution's passing will be a firm, welcomed step in the direction toward equality and justice.
The Anglo-Ashanti Treaty

Border conflicts with the Ashanti Empire have been a constant occurrence since we first established our colony on the Gold Coast. With it obvious, though, that the Ashanti cannot fully repel our troops and retake that land, perhaps we should send them an ultimatum. We shall force an agreement that our borders will lie on the opposite banks of the Pra River, the natural boundary of the Gold Coast colony. Of course, there's nothing stopping us from eventually breaking this treaty and conquering them entirely.

Border conflicts with the British are continuing with no end in sight, lest one of us falls entirely or agrees to peace terms. Britain has come to us with an ultimatum: that we recognize their sovereignty over the Gold Coast colony and share a natural border along the Pra River. This will put us at peace for the meantime and, unfortunately, leave our brethren on the coast at Britain's whim. But war is tiring, and we've certainly had our share of it.
The Ashanti have accepted our peace offer. We can lay down our arms and rest assured that the next time we go to war with them, they will stand no chance.

Our peace offer to the Ashanti Empire is dead in the water. If we ever felt guilt over killing these poor tribespeople--well, think back to how they turned Colonel Governor McCarthy's skull into a gold-plated drinking cup. Now we can look forward to drinking wine aplenty from their skulls.
The Regulamentul Organic

While the Romanian principalities of Wallachia and Moladvia are Ottoman vassals, we have retained garrisons in them since the war of 1828-29. The populace is becoming increasingly resentful of this, especially as we have confiscated Wallachia and Moldavia's treasuries for the time being. It is up to us to shape their governments for the better and hand them back control over their finances. The proposed Organic Regulation would form the organic law, or legal system forming the basis of government, of the principalities. It would establish a national assembly in Iasi and Bucharest elected by no more than 3000 of the most influential citizens. Furthermore, the Organic Regulation would, among other things, ensure the independence of the judiciary and establish a poll tax in place of the old indirect taxes.

Russia has imposed a legal system forming the basis of government on us:  the so-called Regulamentul Organic, or "Organic Regulation." This semi-constitutional document returns to us the Russian-confiscated treasury, establishes a national assembly elected by the three thousand most influential citizens, ensures the independence of the judiciary and replaces the old indirect taxes with a poll tax among many other reforms.

The government of José María Vargas has become opposed by a growing movement for the restoration of Gran Colombia. The rebels are led by heroes of the war of independence, including Santiago Mariño, Diego Ibarra and José Laurencio Silva, all formerly loyalists to the Bolivarian cause. They have rallied their forces in the city of Maracaibo and begun marching East to take Caracas. Now, in turn, José Antonio Páez, the man who split Venezuela from Gran Colombia and spelled its doom has returned from retirement and assembled militia to join the struggle on the government's side. It seems that the old rivalry between proponents and detractors of Gran Colombia is to play out one final time--on the battlefield.
The Peruvian Constitution of $YEAR$

Now that the Bermudists have been defeated, we can finally set about finishing the new constitution. The proposed draft mostly reiterates the 1828 constitution and follows its liberal spirit but makes some adjustments to combat instability which has been experienced since. For example, the post of vice-president would be removed due to the bad contact of former VP Antonio Gutiérrez de la Fuente. Another example is the prohibition of immediate presidential reelection, a tactic used by Augustín Gamarra to elongate his presidency.

The 1828 Constitution had agreed that in 1833, five years later, a new constitution would be formulated to adapt to the new situation of our country and possibly implement a federal system. Thus, a constitutional congress has gathered and heald a vote to elect a provisional president until the new constitution is finished. Pretenders for the position were the liberal Luis José de Obregoso, the conservative Pedro Pablo Bermúdez and the independent Domingo Nieto. Obregoso won with 47 votes to Bermúdez's 36 and Nieto's 1.

Pedro Pablo Bermúdez has rejected the result of the constitutional convention's election of José de Obregoso and risen up in revolt, beginning a civil war. While Bermúdez enjoys the support of most of the army, the populace of Lima and Arequipa are on the side of Obregoso, forcing Bermudist troops to retreat from the cities, unable to capture them with the adamant opposition of the populace.

The civil war has been divided along three fronts: The Orbegosista General Domingo Nieto faced off against the Bermudista General Miguel de San Román in the South, General Felipe Santiago Salaverry fought General Francisco de Vidal in the North and General Luis José de Orbegoso battled General Pedro Bermúdez himself in the central mountains east of Lima. After a number of minor skirmishes over the past few months, the Bermudista officers have lost morale. Without popular support, they have recognized that theirs is a lost cause, and decided to depose Bermúdez from the leadership of the rebel army. Upon reaching the Maquinhuayo Plain, the former Bermudista forces then encountered the Orbegosistas, who had entered a battle formation. To the surprise of the Orbegosistas, the former Bermudistas laid down their arms, whereupon both armies met each other and the soldiers clasped in a fraternal embrace. The civil war is over, and Peru is once again at peace.

The Belgian Constitution

Belgium's existence is extraordinary, considering how divided along linguistic and cultural lines our two major ethnic groups are. Nevertheless, it is our duty to consolidate our brand-new nation, uniting the Flemish, the Walloons and the small German minority. We shall create a constitutional monarchy, a compromise between liberals and the conservatives. The state will have three branches of government and afford privileges to the Catholic Church. Basic freedoms such as that of expression, worship, and the press will be guaranteed. However, only landed subjects will be able to vote.

The lyrics of La Brabançonne, a song that has become a rallying cry for Belgian nationalism, were written by a French mercenary serving in Brussels who died in action. The first version of the lyrics originally scolded rioters and claimed that the Dutch Prince of Orange would be an "example for kings" and a "father to Belgium" if he granted Belgium independence. However, following the bombardment of Antwerp, the lyrics were altered to condemn the Dutch for their brutality. François van Campenhout set the second version to the tune of "L'Air des lancers polonais" ("Song of the Polish Lancers"), and it was an immediate success.
The people of the Duchy of Luxembourg have also joined the struggle for Belgian independence. However, the fortress-city capital of the province itself remains under Dutch control.

The National Congress has decided that Belgium should be a constitutional monarchy, and so the country needs a king. Anti-Dutch sentiment has ruled out any candidate from the House of Nassau, which is the dynasty of the Dutch king. Supporters of a closer connection with France have proposed the Duke of Nemours, who is the second son of the French King. The candidacy of the Duke of Nemours, however, makes the other great powers uneasy, as it undermines the usefulness of Belgium as a barrier against the French. The British have instead suggested Prince Leopold of Saxe-Coburg as a more neutral option. Other candidates being considered include Duke Auguste of Leuchtenberg, a Bonapartist, and Prince Otho of Bavaria. Our representatives at the ongoing Congress of London report that the Congress prefers Leopold, and choosing otherwise may try the patience of the great powers involved.

The National Congress has decided that Belgium should be a constitutional monarchy, which means that the country needs a king. Current anti-Dutch sentiment has ruled out any candidate from the House of Nassau, which is the dynasty of the Dutch king. The most popular candidate is Prince Leopold of Saxe-Coburg. Leopold had previously been offered the Greek throne, which he rejected over concerns that the Greeks were not being treated fairly. Other candidates being considered include Duke Auguste of Leuchtenberg, a Bonapartist, and Prince Otho of Bavaria.

Belgium has sent us an emissary to propose the coronation of the Duke of Nemours, son of king Louis-Philippe as king of Belgium. While this would give us much influence over Belgium, it would surely attract the ire of the British and Prussians. Additionally, Belgium's industry, which is larger than ours, would, by increased interaction with our economy, hurt French artisans.
King Louis-Philippe has given the go-ahead to the coronation of the Duke of Nemours. Celebrations have begun amid his arrival in Brussels. Belgium finally has a king, and a popular one at that!

The Duke of Nemours, son of king Louis-Philippe of France, has been crowned king of Belgium at the bequest of the provisional government. This act spreads the influence of the French revolution further throughout Europe and endangers the old order. With the Louis-Philippe's son on the throne, Belgium is now a French protectorate in all but name.

Louis-Philippe has refused to let his son become king of France. The reason he gives for this is twofold: On the one hand, he does not wish to raise the ire of the other European powers, specifically Prussia and the UK, by extending his influence. On the other hand, Belgium's industry far outmatches France's and economic intermingling between the two would hurt French artisans.

Belgium has sent us an emissary proposing the coronation of Leopold of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha as their king. While it would definitely increase our influence on Belgium, we would get mixed up in their ongoing conflict with the Dutch. An agreement called the "Treaty of the Eighteen Articles" has been proposed which would agree to the coronation of Leopold under the condition that the matters of Limburg and Luxembourg are for Britain to decide.
The British have outright refused to let Leopold of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha become our king, wanting to have nothing to do with our revolutionary state.
The British have given the OK to the coronation of Leopold of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha. He has already arrived in Brussels amid much jubilation. Belgium finally has a king, and a popular one at that!

The British have agreed to have Leopold be crowned king of Belgium. However, they have demanded that we first sign the so-called "Treaty of the Eighteen Articles." This document would give Britain ultimate authority to decide the fate of Limburg and Luxembourg.

Belgium has agreed to sign the Treaty of the Eighteen Articles in faith that we will make a fair judgment over the issue of Limburg and Luxembourg. Leopold of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha will, after all, be king of Belgium.

Belgium has refused to sign the Treaty of the Eighteen Articles, for they lack faith that we will make a fair judgment over the issue of Limburg and Luxembourg. Leopold of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha will not, after all, be king of Belgium.

Even after the southern provinces had become de facto independent, the Dutch King still hoped for a diplomatic solution that would lessen the blow of losing them. He appointed Prince William as governor of the southern provinces at the beginning of the month and empowered him to form an independent administration there. The experiment was to end within that same month. Few Belgians took the authority of Prince William seriously, and when at the end of the month General Chassé reacted to a disturbance in Antwerp by bombarding the city, the people were galvanized against Dutch rule. Delegates were sent to the national conference at the beginning of the following month with a mandate to cut ties with the House of Orange, and two weeks later the provisional government declared the independence of Belgium. It remains to be seen whether the ongoing Congress of London about the Belgian situation will recognize the new state.

It had seemed that Prince Frederick and his 12,000-strong army would soon restore order to Brussels. The leaders of the revolution had fled the city, and a number of the notable burghers had promised their support. And yet, the city still resisted the prince. Upon entry, soldiers were met in some quarters with stones and bricks thrown from rooftops, and with sniper fire in others. They managed to secure much of the northern city on the first day, advancing as far as the Parc, but there the advance stalled. While the army could have brought the city to heel by bombardment and house-to-house fighting, doing so would have been a bloody affair. Prince Frederick was unwilling to conclude what had been intended as a police action with a massacre, and so, after three days of intermittent skirmishing, he withdrew from the city. The revolutionaries claim this as a great victory and have called for an uprising across the southern provinces.

The hard winter of the previous year, combined with the general economic downturn, has increased existing tensions between the northern and southern provinces. Differences in religion and language, as well as the government's preference for the north, have long created a rift between the two parts of the nation, and the grievances of the southern provinces are published nearly daily in the 'Courrier des Pays-Bas'. This dissatisfaction finally found an expression outside of the pages of a newspaper following a performance in Brussels of 'La Muette de Portici', an opera about the Neapolitan revolution. Attendees leaving after act four precipitated turning an already-agitated crowd outside into a riot, which then spread throughout the city unchecked for two days. Order was eventually restored by an unofficial 'burgher guard'. However, far from ending the trouble, this new force has turned into a revolutionary committee, refuses to allow the military to enter Brussels, and is now demanding a separation between the northern and southern provinces.

France has proposed that we partition Belgium instead of recognizing it. We would receive Ghent and Antwerp, while France would get Wallonia and Brussels, Prussia would be given Luxemburg and Liège, and the Dutch would receive Limburg and Hasselt. Antwerp's port would be the most likely to be used to launch an invasion of our isles with its large, close port. Thus, its control would be immensely beneficial to our defense.

France has proposed that we partition Belgium instead of recognizing it. We would receive Luxemburg and Liège, while France would get Wallonia and Brussels, the UK would be given Ghent and Antwerp, and the Dutch would receive Limburg and Hasselt. Luxemburg and Liège have a large German population that would gladly join us in the future pursuit of German unification. The area is also rich in coal and iron.

Other powers in Europe have refused to agree to the Flahaut plan, denouncing it as unjust to the Belgian cause and unfairly imbalanced to favor us. Thus, without support of the others, the plan cannot go ahead.
With the other powers enthusiastically agreeing, Belgium is soon to be no more. As they have no chance against our combined might, the partition is already proceeding without opposition.

France, the UK, Prussia and the Netherlands have agreed to partition us in the so-called Flahaut Plan. Faced with the might of all Western European great powers working together, we have no choice but to surrender.

France, the UK and Prussia have worked out a deal to partition Belgium in the so-called Flahaut Plan. Faced with the might of all Western European great powers working together, Belgium has no choice but to surrender. We will receive Limburg and Hasselt--a fraction of the territory lost, but still better than nothing.
The Flahaut Plan

Belgium has no right to exist. Its people speak Dutch, French and German, an amalgamation utterly undeserving of a nation-state of its own. Therefore, it would be best to divide its lands. With us receiving Wallonia and Brussels, Prussia getting Luxembourg and Liège, the UK being given Antwerp and Ghent, and the Netherlands receiving Limburg and Hasselt, the Western European great powers would surely all be on board.

The Assamese kingdom of Kachari was assisted by British forces in its liberation from Burmese occupation in the Anglo-Burmese War. It makes up part of the larger region of Assam, a strip of land above Bengal comprising the fertile Brahmaputra river valley. The previous king of Kachari, Govinda Chandra Hasnu, has died and is succeeded by an heir friendly to British interests. This heir, Senapati Tularam Thaosen, is willing to give up the throne in exchange for British protection--allowing us to annex Kachari into the East India Company.
Install Purandar Singha

We would love nothing more than to control all of Assam for its rich farmland and the expansion of Britain's markets in India. The locals, however, do not easily consent to foreign rule. There is a way around this: we could restore native autonomy in the region by installing a king as tributary. The king we have in mind is Purandar Singha, a prince of the Ahom Kingdom. Under our plan, he will be installed as a ruler in Upper Assam, guaranteeing our undisputed dominance in the region without directly governing it.

We are creeping further and further toward losing the Southern Provinces due to the increasingly widespread revolution. The revolutionaries have even coronated their first king, making their nationhood already apparent and their independence seemingly inevitable. This nation-building must halt. We will need to commit as many troops as possible to destroying the revolution. This is all-out war.

The Dutch have crossed into Antwerp province, ready to engage our forces and crush our noble revolution. As of now, they are advancing into the forests around Ravels, and Zondereigen has been taken at the cost of 400 Belgian troops being repelled. These troops are clearly better trained and equipped than our own, and their leadership includes the Prince of Orange himself, eager to see his kingdom's reunification through by any means. We must not resign to possible defeat. Our future lies in our own hands, not the House of Orange's.

The separatist Kingdom of Belgium requests our support in fighting off the Dutch for independence. Helping them is tempting, as it weakens the Netherlands and allows us to possibly place a new country on our border under our thumbs. Our people will also doubtlessly sympathize with Belgium's Walloons, who speak a Gallo-Romance dialect similar to French and were made our subjects during Napoleon I's rule.

The rebels now have French backing. Should we continue our counterrevolution, we will need to contend with possible war with France, which would mean digging a hole for ourselves we may not be able to climb out of. Yet our dream of the Low Countries' unification still burns in our hearts. Is it worth surrendering that righteous dream now?
The French have accepted our plea for support! We shall charge together at the Dutch menace, humming La Marseillaise as we fire every round in the name of our liberation.
The dastardly Dutch would rather flee than face us alongside the French on the battlefield. They have retreated from Belgium and all but surrendered our land to its inevitable liberation!
The Dutch would rather flee than face us on the battlefield. They have retreated from Belgium and all but surrendered her Southern Provinces to their liberation.

Samos, an archipelago of culturally Greek islands just off the Turkish side of Ionia, did not join Greece after the 1821 revolt, despite having fought against our invasions of the islands. Instead, Samian rebel leader Lykourgos Logothetis declared Samos an independent state that nonetheless would not accept Ottoman suzerainty. Well, words are meaningless if they cannot be backed up on the battlefield.

The newly-independent state of Ecuador under conservative president Gabriel García Moreno has become socially unstable. This combined with unsettled border disputes can provide a pretext for military action in the country, in hopes of gaining valuable territories for reuniting the old borders of Gran Colombia.
The Treaty of Pasto

Our invasion of Cauca can now end with the signing of a treaty. We shall negotiate the acknowledgment of a border between Colombia and Ecuador along the Carchi River, with the province of Pasto annexed into our territory. With this being our final agreed-upon borders after the dissolution of Gran Colombia, we will no longer have any hostilities with each other and can begin meaningful diplomatic relations.

Troops from $FROM$ have crossed into the Valley of Cauca, presumably looking to start a fight over our disputed northern border. It is no secret that the New Granadans wish to reunite Gran Colombia, whose ashes we emerged from as a free nation. We must prepare our military to respond decisively and turn the tides of this new war.

The Western great powers have convened to recognize the independence of Greece and organize it in their image as a European-style monarchy. They have agreed that Greece's borders shall span from the Cyclades to just below Thessaly, creating a small but regionally significant state friendly to Western Europe's interests in the Mediterranean. However, we will still keep a large majority of ethnically Greek lands, including Epirus, Macedonia, and Thrace, while Egypt will be ceded Crete for helping suppress the revolt there. As for the monarch, the western powers are eyeing Prince Otto of Bavaria as the new King of the Greeks.

The Ottoman Empire has agreed to the terms of the London Protocol, a pact between the UK, Russia, and France to recognize our independence and organize our nation into a monarchy. Both the Ottomans and the West agree that our borders shall span from the Cyclades to just below Thessaly, creating a small but regionally significant state that will provide a buffer to Ottoman expansion. However, the Ottomans will still keep a large majority of ethnically Greek lands, including Thessaly, Epirus, Macedonia, and Thrace, while Egypt will be ceded Crete for helping suppress the revolt there. As for the monarch, the western powers are eyeing Prince Otto of Bavaria as the new King of the Greeks.

The Ottoman Empire has rejected the terms of the London Protocol, a pact between the UK, Russia, and France to recognize our independence and organize our nation into a monarchy. We had hoped to win our independence by any means, and would have readily accepted the terms despite their generosity to the Ottomans--but now our fight has become all the more dire. The revolution must not die!

The Ottoman Empire has rejected the terms of the London Protocol, a pact between the UK, Russia, and France to recognize Greece's independence and organize it into a monarchy. The Greeks had hoped to win their independence by any means, and would have readily accepted the terms despite their generosity to the Ottomans--but now their fight has become all the more dire. As a signatory of the London Protocol, it is our duty to save Greece.

Greece has rejected the terms of the London Protocol, insisting there is far more land that must be liberated. Foolishly turning their backs on the European great powers willing to sponsor their independence, they have diplomatically isolated themselves, leaving them no worthwhile allies in their futile struggle.
